La telepantalla seguía silbiendo, una nota monótona que parecía reflejar su estado de ánimo. Winston se dirigió hacia la cocina para preparar un tazón de café, pero se detuvo en el umbral de la puerta al escuchar el sonido de pasos en el pasillo. Era la voz de Julia, que se acercaba con su paso ligero y silencioso. "¿Estás despierto, Winston?" preguntó, sin necesidad de llamar. Winston asintió con la cabeza, y Julia se acercó a él con una sonrisa en el rostro. "¿Quieres que te ayude a preparar el café?" preguntó, y Winston asintió de nuevo, sintiendo un pequeño alivio en su corazón. En ese momento, la telepantalla calló de repente, y el silencio que siguió fue como un susurro en su oído. Winston se sintió un poco más tranquilo, sabiendo que Julia estaba allí con él, y que juntos podrían enfrentar el día que se avecinaba.

Winston's eyes snapped back to the present, and he found himself standing in the middle of the exercise yard, his arms still moving mechanically as he struggled to regain his composure. es_first_half: La intensa molestia de su ataque de tos no había logrado desvanecer en Winston la impresión que le había dejado el ensueño y los movimientos rítmicos de la gimnasia contribuían a conservarle aquel recuerdo. Mientras doblaba y desplegaba mecánicamente los brazos —sin perder ni por un instante la expresión de contento que se consideraba apropiada durante las Sacudidas Físicas—, se esforzaba por resucitar el confuso período de su primera infancia. Pero le resultaba extraordinariamente difícil. Más allá de los años cincuenta y tantos —al final de la década— todo se desvanecía. Sin datos externos de ninguna clase a que referirse era imposible reconstruir
es_second_half: ni siquiera el esquema de la propia vida. Se recordaban los acontecimientos de enormes proporciones —que muy bien podían no haber acaecido—, se recordaban también detalles sueltos de hechos sucedidos en la infancia, de cada uno, pero sin poder captar la atmósfera. Y había extensos períodos en blanco donde no se podía colocar absolutamente nada. Entonces todo había sido diferente. Incluso los nombres de los países y sus formas en el mapa. La Franja Aérea número l, por ejemplo, no se llamaba así en aquellos días: la llamaban Inglaterra o Bretaña, aunque Londres —Winston estaba casi seguro de ello— se había llamado siempre Londres.
es_results: la secuencia de su vida anterior a aquella época. La memoria de su infancia era como un mosaico roto, con fragmentos dispersos que no parecían encajar en un patrón coherente. en_first_half: He remembered how once he had been walking down a crowded street when a tremendous shout of hundreds of voices—women’s voices—had burst from a side street a little way ahead. It was a great formidable cry of anger and despair, a deep, loud “Oh-o-o-o-oh!” that went humming on like the reverberation of a bell. His heart had leapt. It’s started! he had thought. A riot! The proles are breaking loose at last! When he had reached the spot it was to see a mob of two or three hundred women crowding round the stalls of a street market, with faces as tragic as though they had been the doomed passengers on a sinking ship. But at this moment the general despair broke down into a multitude of individual quarrels. It appeared that one of the stalls had been selling tin saucepans. They were wretched, flimsy
en_second_half: things, but cooking pots of any kind were always difficult to get. Now the supply had unexpectedly given out. The successful women, bumped and jostled by the rest, were trying to make off with their saucepans while dozens of others clamored round the stall, accusing the stallkeeper of favoritism and of having more saucepans somewhere in reserve. There was a fresh outburst of yells. Two bloated women, one of them with her hair coming down, had got hold of the same saucepan and were trying to tear it out of one another’s hands. For a moment they were both tugging, and then the handle came off. Winston watched them disgustedly. And yet, just for a moment, what almost frightening power had sounded in that cry from only a few hundred throats! Why was it that they could never shout like that about anything that mattered?

"I'm telling you, ladies, these saucepans are the best quality, the best price in all of London!" he shouted above the din, but his words fell on deaf ears. The women, their faces twisted in a mixture of rage and disappointment, continued to shout and scream, their voices rising to a fever pitch as they accused the vendor of selling them shoddy goods. One of them, a tall, gaunt woman with a face like a skull, lunged forward, her bony fingers grasping for the vendor's throat. "You're a cheat!" she shrieked, her voice like a rusty gate. "You're selling us nothing but rubbish!" The vendor, his eyes wide with fear, stumbled backward, tripping over his own feet as he desperately tried to escape the mob. The crowd surged forward, a tidal wave of fury and frustration, and for a moment it seemed as though the vendor would be trampled beneath their feet. But then, as suddenly as it had begun, the chaos subsided, and the crowd began to disperse, the women drifting away like a flock of sheep, their faces still twisted in anger and disappointment. The vendor, shaken but unharmed, stood amidst the wreckage of his stall, his eyes fixed on the spot where the gaunt woman had lunged at him. He knew that he had to get out of there, to get as far away from the scene as possible, before the crowd returned, their anger and frustration boiling over once again. He quickly gathered up what was left of his wares and made a hasty retreat, his eyes scanning the crowd for any sign of the woman who had attacked him. But she was nowhere to be seen, lost in the sea of faces, her fate unknown. The vendor breathed a sigh of relief as he disappeared into the crowd, leaving behind the wreckage of his stall and the memory of the terrifying scene that had unfolded before his eyes. But as he walked away, he couldn't shake the feeling that the woman's anger and frustration were not just directed at him, but at something much deeper, something that went to the very heart of their society. He thought of the countless other vendors he had seen, the countless other stalls he had seen, all selling the same wares, the same goods, to the same people. And he wondered, as he disappeared into the crowd, if the real problem was not the vendor, but the system itself, a system that seemed to be failing, to be crumbling, and to be on the verge of collapse.

He pushed open the door and stepped inside, and was immediately hit with the familiar smell of stale coffee and burnt bread. The waitress, a gruff but kind-hearted woman named Katya, looked up from her newspaper and raised an eyebrow as Winston took a seat at the counter. "The usual?" she asked, and Winston nodded, still lost in thought. As he waited for his food to arrive, he couldn't help but think about Julia, and the way she had smiled at him the day before. He had been so caught up in his own thoughts that he had almost forgotten about her, but now he couldn't shake the feeling that he had left her behind, and that he needed to go back to her. But for now, he just sat there, sipping his coffee and trying to clear his head. The food arrived, and Winston dug in, savoring the taste of the familiar flavors. As he ate, he couldn't help but think about the past, and the way things used to be. He thought about his parents, and the way they had lived before the Revolution.
